hints_html: A function is increasing when its slope is positive.
hints_latex: A function is increasing when its slope is positive.
hints_raw: A function is increasing when its slope is positive.
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
The given function is increasing where its first derivative is positive. Taking the derivative yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = 2x - 1/x\end{aligned}\]

We must now solve the inequality for x yields the interval where \(f\) is increasing. We will only be interested in positive values of x, as negative values of x are not in the domain of the given function (because of the natural logarithm). Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} 0 &< 2x - 1/x , \quad x > 0\\ 1/x &< 2x \\ 1 & < 2x^2 \\ \frac{1}{2} &< x^2 \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we have

\[\begin{aligned} x > + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{aligned}\]

The negative solution was ruled out because of the requirement that x be a positive number.

The interval on which \(f\) is increasing is

\[\begin{aligned} \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \infty\right)\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The given function is increasing where its first derivative is positive. Taking the derivative yields

:<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = 2x - 1/x</math>

We must now solve the inequality for ''x'' yields the interval where &fnof; is increasing. We will only be interested in positive values of ''x'', as negative values of ''x'' are not in the domain of the given function (because of the natural logarithm). Therefore,

:<math>\begin{align}
0 &< 2x - 1/x , \quad x > 0\\
1/x &< 2x \\
1 & < 2x^2 \\
\frac{1}{2} &< x^2 \\
\end{align}
</math>
Therefore, we have 

:<math>
x > + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
</math>

The negative solution was ruled out because of the requirement that ''x'' be a positive number. 

The interval on which &fnof; is increasing is

:<math>
\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \infty\right)
</math>
statement_html:
Find the interval(s) on which

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = x^2 - \ln(x)\end{aligned}\]

is increasing.
statement_raw:
Find the interval(s) on which 

:<math>\displaystyle f(x) = x^2 - \ln(x)</math>

is increasing.
